text: hi so i'm leah shepherd i'm currently a
phd candidate at the sauder school of
business at the university of british
columbia
and thank you very much for inviting me
to be here today i'm really excited to
talk about
some of my ideas and research on the
topic of women's same-sex conflict at
work
so um when i originally got interested
in this topic it was during my master's
degree
and i knew at that time that i
was really fascinated by under any kind
of gender stereotyping research
uh particularly in the context of the
workplace but i had felt this i think
very common feeling of everything's been
done how can i possibly contribute in
some way
and then i had a conversation with my
mother and i think i was mentioning this
to her that i was sort of confused and i
didn't know what i could do
what would be interesting for me and
what would be interesting for the
literature
and she said well what about
competition between women at work and i
said well what do you mean and she went
on to tell me a story about her current
workplace and a very difficult
relationship that she seemed to be
having with her female boss
and so she was very much coming at it
from a perspective of yeah you know
women must have these unique
difficulties with one another
and why is that and so that's very much
the place that i was coming at this
problem from i was thinking okay are
women mean girls at work uh why are they
they having
problems with one another why are there
relationships more competitive than
cooperative
and i didn't have a lot of personal
experience to draw from but i i seem to
find a lot of anecdotal evidence to
support this and like robin presented
all these books that have been written
about this topic
they're very much approaching this from
the same perspective of mean girls grown
up at work and there's there's a lot of
books an astonishing number of books
about this only one of which i've read
but um
so yeah so this was the perspective that
i was that i was coming from and i think
that there is some truth to that
perspective i'm not here to try to say
that women would not have any unique
difficulties and i think that there's
been good reason presented before me to
show that this could be the case
that there's probably some truth to this
but i also think that there might be a
little bit of an exaggerated stereotype
and i think this has been touched on as
well before by um our the earlier
presenters just talking about you know
this this catty stereotype um and i
think it's sort of been overblown and
i'm i'm now thinking more about okay
well why is that and why is it that we
seem to react very negatively to female
same-sex conflict where it's very
salient to us we take notice of it and
we seek to explain it and we wonder why
women aren't being overly supportive of
one another and i started to think more
about okay well what's our fascination
with that and then what implications
could that also have for women's
relationships if we're constantly
putting them under the microscope
and assuming the worse and then reacting
also very negatively to women's same-sex
conflict because we know that conflict
is sometimes necessary in organizations
and anytime that two women are engaged
in a conflict it doesn't necessarily
mean that that there's a problem there
could just be that's that's the nature
of work
so anyone who's a seinfeld fan will
maybe recognize this scene um where
elaine is having a problem with a
co-worker a female co-worker
and everyone's just talking about it as
a cat fight that's the only attention
that it's getting a very negative type
of attention
so what i think might be happening here
is that
there's some prescriptions about the way
that women should behave in relation to
one another
and we know from a lot of past research
that there's just general prescriptions
about women too women and men so we
think that you know women should be very
warm and nurturing and cooperative
and that there's a backlash effect when
women violate that so that if they don't
come across as being very warm and
cooperative they they then are seen as
being very hostile and and cold
and i think that when it comes to when
we take that to the dyadic level and we
think about women's behavior towards
other women there's an additional
prescription that comes into place which
is that women should be very supportive
of one another that it's very important
for the cause of gender equality that
they do that
and so there's some evidence about this
prescription this is some some quotes
here so a very famous and often repeated
quote by madeleine albright there's a
special place in hell for women who
don't help other women
some celebrities were chimed in i don't
like women slaughtering women we're all
just so mean
and then even chelsea handler i think as
a woman you have a responsibility to
take care of other women
and i think that this prescription is
behind a lot of the backlash also
towards marissa meyer ceo of yahoo so
she's held to a standard where not only
does she need to be a great ceo and and
save a company that for a while there
was flailing and maybe now she's she's
improved the situation quite a bit
but she's also expected to make
decisions that benefit other women
so when she decided to scale back the
work from home program that they had at
yahoo about about a year ago now
she received a lot of backlash about
this and what was really interesting
about that was that a lot of companies
big companies
uh in you know the year preceding that
decision had also made a similar
decision so some companies find that you
know work from home doesn't work for
them
um and but it was the backlash was was
placed a lot on marissa meyer where you
really didn't hear about these other
organizations with male ceos who had
made the same decision
and so she was clearly held to the
standard of she needs to be not only a
great ceo but also a great ceo who
represents the interests of other women
and that's what she should be doing
so we see here when marissa meyer
directed all employees never to work
from home i understood why she said she
isn't a feminist maybe she really isn't
and so i started to sort of search for
evidence of this prescription beyond
just this anecdotal evidence that i was
seeing and in a survey of working adults
i found that 74 agree with the statement
if women wish to improve their
collective standing in society they must
work together
and
participants were also significantly
more likely to agree with a statement
about women should be good to one
another than about the statement
men should be good to one another and
what was really interesting and which
tells me that this is probably a very
well-intentioned
prescription is that the difference in
agreement between those two statements
was the largest for individuals who
scored very highly on a liberal
political ideology scale so presumably
this prescription is coming from a very
good place of we want to see women we
want to see women in high ranking
leadership roles we want to see more
equality and so we really want you know
we really do believe then that women
have to support one another and lend a
helping hand and and and it's their
responsibility then to engage in that
but i think though that this can be also
a little bit dangerous having this
prescription while it's wonderful to see
women working together we might want to
be careful about how much we use the
word should that women should be
engaging in in some type of behavior
because that prescription like a lot of
other prescriptions really limits
women's behavior
and so
in a first study i was interested in
beyond just the survey and this was an
experimental study
uh i was interested in sort of
documenting what might happen when a
woman undermines the interests of
another woman at work so i was thinking
very much from the example of of marissa
meyer it was very it was a very
different example that i used in my
scenario but that's sort of what
inspired that research
and so i had the same scenario and it
involved
a meeting about performance that was
happening in a law firm
and so i had uh some senior partners who
had who had met to discuss the
performance of some of the associates
with the associates not there
and i set up a scenario where it was
either
participants were randomly assigned to
read either about a
senior partner who was female she was
janet or jeffrey male
and this individual then gave some
negative
feedback um not not personal or hostile
just simply i don't really think this
person is cut out for this profession
they don't really seem to be very
committed to their caseloads they're
very passionate about what they're doing
so very very standard
but this was directed at either a female
or male associate so either helen or
brad
and so i just sort of gave participants
free reign because i was really
interested to see what they said about
this so i just simply asked them
why do you think that janet said this
about helen or janet said this about
brad
and then i coded these responses and i
ended up coming up with four categories
and this was determined by me and then
also a research assistant who was you
know blind to what i was studying
uh and four categories emerged which was
person related task related sexism and
and miscellaneous just i don't know or
participants who maybe weren't that
engaged in the experiment
uh and so the person related responses
the person really fortunately there
weren't very many of them um the the
person-related responses had to do a lot
with these themes of disliking and
threat um and so she is jealous of helen
or he is threatened by helen
uh and then the task related were just
sort of you know well the participant
was presumably just taking the
information that was provided to them
you know this person is clearly just not
a good performer they're not doing very
well
and then sexism which was only coming
through when it was a male partner and
female associate uh
and not really the focus of of what i
was interested in but just uh to be
thorough so
he does not see women as equals there's
you know limited capability there
because of because of the fact that this
person is a woman
and then what i found was that you can
see here what's really interesting is
that when there was a female partner who
was giving this negative feedback about
a female associate the vast majority of
the reasons that were provided had to do
with person-related causes and this was
pretty astonishing when i when i saw
this because it was just very much you
know she is threatened she is jealous of
this person
um and then we see that in all of the
other other categories uh it's the task
related that tends to outnumber the
person related and this did this was
statistically significant it was
in this female female
quadrant participants were more likely
to attribute this negative evaluation to
some type of person related cause which
which was a bit concerning i think
because it was such a
mildly negative
feedback so it really made me think
about you know when women are engaged in
these settings in workplaces which i'm
sure they're often are where they're
giving negative feedback
and not even directly to the individual
but when they're just
expressing an opinion
whether or not whether this is coming
into play which could you know really be
detrimental for those women their
opinion could be dismissed based on well
she's clearly just catty she's clearly
just competitive
and so then in the next study i was sort
of interested this the first one was
looking at you know very much the
backlash that this single woman received
but i started to think more about you
know whether conflict
is also just problematized when it's
occurring between two women
and so this study was looking at uh just
the same workplace conflict
with only again the names differing so
either a female female conflict male
male or mixed
and i was really interested in seeing um
what participants thought would be the
outcome of these types of conflicts so
did they think that these people would
be able to
eventually come to some conclusion
resolve their conflict move on work
together productively
and then also what about personal
implications did they see did they think
that the people that were involved one
or more of the individuals involved in
the conflict would also have some
personal difficulties in terms of maybe
decreased job satisfaction or decreased
commitment or even higher turnover
intentions
and so what i found was that um so it
wasn't just enough you didn't see this
problematic problematization occur with
just one female in the conflict it had
to be it was mainly in this this female
female dyad and so lower levels are less
perceived relationship repair so as you
can see that the female female conflict
was coming through with the the lowest
amounts of perceived relationship repair
so participants didn't think that these
people would be able to overcome their
difficulties and repair the relationship
to the same extent that the the males in
the male male conflict or the male and
female in the mixed conflict would be
able to
and for perceived negative personal
implications and we see higher values
are more negative uh personal
implications we see again female female
is is being perceived as the most
problematic or worse in this scenario
and then i started to notice that there
was a trend in my data so there was i
was
always including gender participant
gender as a potential variable of
interest
would it diff differ would women see
this any differently than men and the
answer is no i in both of those studies
there's no interaction with participant
gender and so then i started to think
okay so women then are also
holding these views
about other women's relationships but
then what about their own how does that
lead into how they react to their own
conflict or the behavior that they
receive from other women how does this
how does this prescription and this
problematization
uh influence their perspective and
another sort of personal inspiration for
this this next study was my own
recognition that i had recently engaged
and uh had had a disagreement with a
female supervisor
and and i think this is very common in
in grad school there's there's tons of
disagreements that happen with with
people that you're working with but
noticing that i had been visibly more
distressed about that
conflict if you could even really call
it that
relative to conflicts that i'd had with
a male supervisor which just sort of
seemed like well it'll be all fine we'll
figure it out
and there wasn't as much of a distress
on my part and so i started thinking
about that as well
and so i think we have this picture as
sort of like the ideal female
relationship in which everyone's very
supportive and i thought about what
implications that could have
for for
uh women's reactions to other women's
behavior and then also the quality of
women's relationships
so i conducted a study where i had male
and female participants they were
randomly assigned to a scenario in which
they're
they're always being asked to imagine
themselves in a scenario in which they
had reached out to someone who they
would like to be a mentor and ask for
some guidance but also tried to build
more of a personal relationship with
that person and that person was either
male or female
and then they kind of got a very cold
response back it was very terse at least
the person had responded probably the
type of response you might imagine from
someone who's very very busy but didn't
you know didn't include a lot of
niceties and and just was kind of kind
of straightforward and to the point and
didn't do much for helping build this
relationship further and so i wanted to
see what participants reactions to that
would be if they were to imagine
themselves in this situation
um and so how would they feel about it
but then also what were their
perceptions of this person who they
originally had a lot of respect for and
and would have liked to have as a mentor
and what i found was that female
participants who had been assigned to
the female would be meant to our
condition felt more disappointed and let
down by this scenario which then
actually led them to rate the would-be
mentor as being more cold
and so i thought this could have and of
course i need to do some more research
to see okay well what then and and what
implications could that have for women's
relationships but it really got me
thinking about you know what then
happens to women's relationships when a
perceived betrayal or just cold
treatment even if it's not intended to
be that way it just kind of comes across
that way
what implications does that then have
for that relationship do females feel
you know more let down do they then sort
of withdraw and avoid dealing with that
person
which we would probably expect could
just exacerbate the situation and maybe
even turn into a full-blown conflict
which we certainly wouldn't want
um so i you know i kind of need to do
more research in that domain but it's
sort of an interesting initial
uh peek into perhaps women's
expectations or the prescriptions that
they hold other women
to in their relationships
and so some of my conclusions from this
research have been that we you know
while while we want we certainly do tend
to want to see female solidarity we do
need to maybe proceed with caution about
making that a prescription and
whether we hold women to that standard
um and you know probably avoiding
judging women who maybe don't engage in
in tons of supportive behavior towards
other women so i think that some of
these stereotypes that we've created
that that exist as of now
um could be dangerous and and perhaps
could create self-fulfilling prophecies
so i wonder too whether you know a lot
of
whether because of this stereotype um
supportive
uh
supportive interactions between women
just kind of fly under our radar and
even as women maybe you know if we get a
lot of support from a woman that's
what's expected right we would expect
her to be that way so we don't really
take too much notice of those events but
then do we overly focus on the negative
experiences that we have making them
much more salient and kind of leading us
to this conclusion that yeah you know
women women are awful to one another
they have they have these uh they have
these uh
very tense relationships
so yeah female solidarity of course is
wonderful but we want to think about
whether it's fair to push this ideal on
women whether it's another thing now
that women have to worry about doing in
addition to all kinds of other things
that they're already worrying about in
organizations
and we probably need to adjust some of
our our personal uh prescriptions that
we have towards the women in our life so
thinking about uh you know whether or
not we are constantly uh deserving of of
support that those women have their own

and it's not really fair to be pushing
